content.description: Biologists are analyzing soil to check for the number of worms and grubs in a wildlife preserve. Let the random variable <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the number of worms found in 1 square foot of soil, and let the random variable <math alttext="G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the number of grubs found in 1 square foot of soil. The following tables show the probability distributions developed by the biologists for <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
content.question: <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 Probability 0.05 0.06 0.18 0.35 0.30 0.05 0.01 <math alttext="G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> 0 1 2 3 4 5 6 Probability 0.05 0.21 0.27 0.38 0.05 0.03 0.01 Assume that the distributions of worms and grubs are independent. What are the mean, <math alttext="mu" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></math>, and standard deviation, <math alttext="sigma" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>σ</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the total number of worms and grubs in 1 square foot of soil?

choices.label: <math alttext="mu equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="sigma equals 1.67" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.67</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="mu equals 5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="sigma equals 2.36" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.36</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="mu equals 5.28" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5.28</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="sigma equals 1.67" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.67</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="mu equals 5.28" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5.28</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="sigma equals 2.36" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.36</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="mu equals 5.28" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5.28</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="sigma equals 2.79" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.79</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="mu equals 5.28" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5.28</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="sigma equals 1.67" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.67</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 4: Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions

skill.text: Skill 3.B: Determine parameters for probability distributions.
